title: Can I speak about someone's book without their permission? If it is not possible, how should I contact the author of the book? - Quora
tags: Legal Issues and Law in Everyday Life

response.answer_text: Speak about it? Of course you can do that. Review and criticism are absolutely allowed, as is discussion of a book’s plot, theme, and other literary elements. If it were only possible to discuss a book with permission from the author, you’d never see a negative review. That’s not a particularly good outcome, even though some authors might be fond of it. You are absolutely allowed to express your thoughts about any work, including a book. In most jurisdictions, there is even an exception to copyright (called “fair use” in the US, and by numerous other names worldwide) that permits you to use small portions from a copyrighted work to illustrate one’s point in a review. So if, for example, your review is that the dialogue is lackluster and stilted, you could generally include a short snippet of dialogue from the book to illustrate exactly what you’re talking about.

it is fine to speak of their work, even quoting it as long as you attribute the statement or research to them. That is what footnotes are for in journalistic articles on a particular subject. Often new works are built on deriving consensus or refuting prior publication. Be meticulous in your use of their work and you shouldn’t have any problems.
How have you never heard someone talk about Lord of the Rings, Harry Potter, or Game of Thrones? Book reviews ateafe without permission.
